text: [Applause]
This year, one of our major goals is to
make animating linear content in engine
awesome. We've got a lot of work to do
still, but the 56 release is packed with
new features that have been influenced
and battle tested by some of the world's
best studios. One of them is here with
us today. The third floor has an
impressive track record of using Unreal
to make movies like Guardians of the
Galaxy and shows like House of the
Dragon. Here to tell you about their
next incredible production is
co-director of the new Predator movie,
Josh
Wasan. In March 2020, I was working with
director Dan Trappenberg on the pitch
for Prey when everyone got sent home. We
had been dreaming of pushing previs into
animation for years and had just
finished our UEIE pipeline for the
Mandalorian.
Uncertain what would happen to movies in
a postcoid era. Now was the time for
third floor to get serious about finals.
So while we're having a blast crafting
scenes and UE for Prey, I got to show
Dan the cool things we had brewing. And
that led to an idea. What if Predator
was an animated movie? Fast forward to
the industry contraction of 2023 and
projects started dropping like flies.
But this crazy ambitious film with a
crazy ambitious schedule materialized
right in the middle of it all. For 20
years on more than 1,000 projects at the
artists at TTF have been on the front
lines of visual storytelling in movies,
games, and episodics. When Predator came
along, they took all of that liveaction
experience, all of their love for cool
stuff and great stories, and poured
their hearts into a new kind of animated
feature. So Dan and I pitched a film
rooted in live action that looks and
feels like moving concept art.
We developed a hand-crafted style from
the paint strokes to our stopmotion
inspired movement on twos. It was a
monumental challenge, but the leap into
anom led to significant innovation. Our
team built Hummingbird, our real time
lighting and comp tool inside UEIE. It
handled all of our stylization passes in
engine before render. We saved countless
render hours and reduced our hard drive
usage to 150th the space traditionally
required.
Now, let me tell you about my favorite
character in the movie. Ursa has this
deep rooted thirst for revenge. She
learns that the man responsible is in
this throne room in this huge fortress.
So, Dan had this idea, what if we did an
entire battle in one shot? What if we
kept the camera focused on her goal? And
what if Ursa fought them all by
herself? The best way to speed up any
production is to speed up decision-m.
So, with four parallel teams inside
Unreal, we got the entire film up on
screen in four months, allowing us to
iterate and hone the story, really make
it sing before shifting into final
animation, ultimately delivering the
film in 18 months. If this movie were
live action, we'd be filming at golden
hour every day for weeks with a massive
crew and several giant vats of blood.
In animation, we really wanted to go for
it. No holding back. So, we
choreographed every composition, every
strike, every arrow, and blood splatter
like a gigantic dance with 98 parts.
Yet, we also wanted to feel the camera
operator reacting to all the kills as
they happen to put you inside this quest
for revenge.
On behalf of 20th Century Studios, Dan
Tractenberg, and all of us at Third
Floor, we hope you enjoy this exclusive
clip from Predator: Killer of Killers.
Sir,
Let's go.
[Applause]
It's the Predator movie. we've always
wanted and it's prevised, assembled,
lit, rendered, and composited all in
Unreal. And it's premiering this Friday
on Hulu. So check it out. And
congratulations to Josh and the team.
